Key Arguments: The legislation poses a major threat to freedom of speech in Australia.
The definition of misinformation is vague and lacks a clear definition of 'serious harm'.
The legislation exempts state and federal governments from its provisions, creating a double standard.
Social media platforms are already adhering to a voluntary code to combat misinformation.
The proposed powers could lead to excessive censorship due to fear of fines.
The legislation could be used as a revenue-raising tool by the government.
Notable Quotes: This is a huge gag on free speech in a piece of legislation and is one of the worst pieces of legislation for free speech ever!
So governments can tell lies, spread misinformation that they call truth, but I could be banned from challenging it?

Itâ€™s highly probable then that these powers would lead media companies and internet platforms to be extremely wary of the threat of fines and costs of having to defend themselves - this would lead to excessive censorship!
